issue.title: debating how to set acceptUnmatched

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
In the filter phase, we have a list of incoming messages.
* we expose them to all reject/accept clauses.
* there are messages which have not been explicitly matched.
What do we do with them?

Currently, we require a manual setting *acceptUnmatched* .

With *acceptUnmatched True*, those files are accepted.

*AcceptUnmatched on* is entirely equivalent to accept .*  (except it is faster because no regex to evaluate. (fixed by faf73a55b9304be800c6e287f339cf2b1ccd5fdb)

We set the default to a fixed value:

in flow/
     __init__.pt : False
    poll: False
    post: False
    report: True
   sarra: True
   sender: True
   subscribe: False
   watch: True
   winnow: True

ugh...  but I think the real issue here is whether there are accept/reject patterns provided.
If we want acceptUmatched to be set to something that makes sense, it would be based on the contents of the accept/reject patterns.

case 1: no patterns at all provided...

* if there are no accepts or rejects provided, then setting acceptUnmatched to False resorts in nothing ever being processed, which is useless. It makes more sense for it to be automatically set to True

case 2: only rejects in patterns... again results in nothing ever being accepted if the default is False... so again it makes sense to set it to True

case 3: only accepts in patterns... seems logical, anything not explicitly accepted is rejected.  So in this case, it should be set to False


case 4: mix of rejects and accepts... seems logical to reject anything not explicitly accepted. so it would be set to False.

If we take the above 4 cases

Say we apply logic: that uses the above four cases to decide what to do.


imagined case 5: started with only rejects...
```

reject my1.*
reject my4.*

```

so take case 2... only rejects in pattern.. so guessing that everything else is accepted... 
If you receive files   

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file

now say you add an accept...

```

reject my1.*
accept my2.*
reject my4.*

```

for the same input flow...

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file

according to case 4, now because you added an accept, acceptUnmatched flips to false so you surprisingly accept fewer files than before...

hmm...  Does that make this more confusing than helpful?

option 1: current state

it just is set to a default per flow, that makes sense.

in v2, many poll configurations from internal examples seem to expect *acceptUnmatched True*, but it is currently False.  Changine that...  ( 5b41ec299df655c1d113ce83820e26a529b3878d )

Ideally, the goal would be to get rid of acceptUnmatched, and just have it do the right thing always, but case 5, makes me thing that getting rid of it is inelegant.  Need a better idea for how to set it automatically.

issue.title: work.age not a good port of v2 file_age

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: Priority 2 - Critical
labels.description: High Criticality or High Visibility Problem

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
the file_age plugin notes how old a file is when a copy is done, by comparing
the time the plugin is called, to the file's mtime at source (recorded in the message.)

The file_age plugin was ported, literally, to work.age, and it does the same thing, 
but with the sr3 way of doing things, the same thing is the wrong thing.  in v2, on_file was called as each file was written, whereas in sr3, messages are processed in batches, so the on_file is called for an entire batch, after the batch has downloaded.   So the timing will be reported as much worse because the logic hasn't been adjusted.

Granted, you can set batch=1 to get v2 behaviour, but in general the transfers happen, and then, some time later, the after_work processing happens.

Fixing this requires some plumbing.  Probably want to add a message field ''timeWritten" ... to the send/download built-in logic ... and then use that in work.age.

note: Internal client (CMOI) uses this plugin as part of HPC mirroring. so this is a blocker for them moving to sr3

issue.title: flows taking a long time to exit

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
So, in the name of ensuring state is saved, there is a signal handler in flow (please_stop) ... but the effect of that signal handler is to catch a sigterm signal, set please_stop flag, but that's it... if a flow is in a sleep... that sleep continues... so if you have a polling interval of 900 seconds, then it will wait to do the cleanup until after that sleep ends normally.

This is a pita in development, and likely will result in sr3 stop losing patience and doing a kill -9...
I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

issue.title: flows taking a long time to exit

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
So, in the name of ensuring state is saved, there is a signal handler in flow (please_stop) ... but the effect of that signal handler is to catch a sigterm signal, set please_stop flag, but that's it... if a flow is in a sleep... that sleep continues... so if you have a polling interval of 900 seconds, then it will wait to do the cleanup until after that sleep ends normally.

This is a pita in development, and likely will result in sr3 stop losing patience and doing a kill -9...
I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

issue.title: downloads fail with directory . specified

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on (outside development scope)

issue.body:
Specifying a dot character *.* as the argument to the directory option is not handled correctly by sarracenia version 2.

given a configuration like so:

```
broker amqps://dd.weather.gc.ca/

# expire, in operational use, should be longer than longest expected interruption
expire 10m
mirror on

subtopic bulletins.alphanumeric.#

directory .
accept .*

```

every download fails, like so:

```

2022-12-01 15:32:18,557 [INFO] reading from to anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca, exchange: xpublic

issue.title: debating how to set acceptUnmatched

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
In the filter phase, we have a list of incoming messages.
* we expose them to all reject/accept clauses.
* there are messages which have not been explicitly matched.
What do we do with them?

Currently, we require a manual setting *acceptUnmatched* .

With *acceptUnmatched True*, those files are accepted.

*AcceptUnmatched on* is entirely equivalent to accept .*  (except it is faster because no regex to evaluate. (fixed by faf73a55b9304be800c6e287f339cf2b1ccd5fdb)

We set the default to a fixed value:

in flow/
     __init__.pt : False
    poll: False
    post: False
    report: True
   sarra: True
   sender: True
   subscribe: False
   watch: True
   winnow: True

ugh...  but I think the real issue here is whether there are accept/reject patterns provided.
If we want acceptUmatched to be set to something that makes sense, it would be based on the contents of the accept/reject patterns.

case 1: no patterns at all provided...

* if there are no accepts or rejects provided, then setting acceptUnmatched to False resorts in nothing ever being processed, which is useless. It makes more sense for it to be automatically set to True

case 2: only rejects in patterns... again results in nothing ever being accepted if the default is False... so again it makes sense to set it to True

case 3: only accepts in patterns... seems logical, anything not explicitly accepted is rejected.  So in this case, it should be set to False


case 4: mix of rejects and accepts... seems logical to reject anything not explicitly accepted. so it would be set to False.

If we take the above 4 cases

Say we apply logic: that uses the above four cases to decide what to do.


imagined case 5: started with only rejects...
```

reject my1.*
reject my4.*

```

so take case 2... only rejects in pattern.. so guessing that everything else is accepted... 
If you receive files   

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file

now say you add an accept...

```

reject my1.*
accept my2.*
reject my4.*

```

for the same input flow...

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file

according to case 4, now because you added an accept, acceptUnmatched flips to false so you surprisingly accept fewer files than before...

hmm...  Does that make this more confusing than helpful?

option 1: current state

it just is set to a default per flow, that makes sense.

in v2, many poll configurations from internal examples seem to expect *acceptUnmatched True*, but it is currently False.  Changine that...  ( 5b41ec299df655c1d113ce83820e26a529b3878d )

Ideally, the goal would be to get rid of acceptUnmatched, and just have it do the right thing always, but case 5, makes me thing that getting rid of it is inelegant.  Need a better idea for how to set it automatically.

issue.title: work.age not a good port of v2 file_age

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: Priority 2 - Critical
labels.description: High Criticality or High Visibility Problem

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
the file_age plugin notes how old a file is when a copy is done, by comparing
the time the plugin is called, to the file's mtime at source (recorded in the message.)

The file_age plugin was ported, literally, to work.age, and it does the same thing, 
but with the sr3 way of doing things, the same thing is the wrong thing.  in v2, on_file was called as each file was written, whereas in sr3, messages are processed in batches, so the on_file is called for an entire batch, after the batch has downloaded.   So the timing will be reported as much worse because the logic hasn't been adjusted.

Granted, you can set batch=1 to get v2 behaviour, but in general the transfers happen, and then, some time later, the after_work processing happens.

Fixing this requires some plumbing.  Probably want to add a message field ''timeWritten" ... to the send/download built-in logic ... and then use that in work.age.

note: Internal client (CMOI) uses this plugin as part of HPC mirroring. so this is a blocker for them moving to sr3

issue.title: flows taking a long time to exit

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
So, in the name of ensuring state is saved, there is a signal handler in flow (please_stop) ... but the effect of that signal handler is to catch a sigterm signal, set please_stop flag, but that's it... if a flow is in a sleep... that sleep continues... so if you have a polling interval of 900 seconds, then it will wait to do the cleanup until after that sleep ends normally.

This is a pita in development, and likely will result in sr3 stop losing patience and doing a kill -9...
I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

*Note: some of these still have FIXMEs and TODOs to take care of since I wasn't always sure about the logic of the plugin*

issue.title: downloads fail with directory . specified

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on (outside development scope)

issue.body:
Specifying a dot character *.* as the argument to the directory option is not handled correctly by sarracenia version 2.

given a configuration like so:

```
broker amqps://dd.weather.gc.ca/

# expire, in operational use, should be longer than longest expected interruption
expire 10m
mirror on

subtopic bulletins.alphanumeric.#

directory .
accept .*

```

every download fails, like so:

```
022-12-01 15:32:18,554 [INFO] Binding queue q_anonymous.sr_subscribe.dd_amis.19381310.19639925 with key v02.post.bulletins.alphanumeric.# from exchange xpublic on broker amqps://anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca/
2022-12-01 15:32:18,556 [INFO] declared queue q_anonymous.sr_subscribe.dd_amis.19381310.19639925 (anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca)
2022-12-01 15:32:18,557 [INFO] reading from to anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca, exchange: xpublic
2022-12-01 15:32:18,559 [INFO] report_back to anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca, exchange: xs_anonymous
2022-12-01 15:32:18,559 [INFO] sr_retry on_heartbeat
2022-12-01 15:32:18,564 [INFO] No retry in list
2022-12-01 15:32:18,566 [INFO] sr_retry on_heartbeat elapse 0.006780
2022-12-01 15:32:18,567 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,569 [WARNING] downloading again, attempt 2
2022-12-01 15:32:18,569 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,570 [WARNING] downloading again, attempt 3
2022-12-01 15:32:18,571 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,573 [INFO] appended to retry list file 20221201152828.419 https://dd2.weather.gc.ca /bulletins/alphanumeric/20221201/SR/KWAL/15/SRCN40_KWAL_011528___46900
```

work-arounds:

* since **directory .** specifies the default behaviour, remove that line. it will download correctly

issue.title: debating how to set acceptUnmatched

labels.name: Design
labels.description: Problem hard to fix, affects design.

labels.name: Developer
labels.description: not a problem, more of a note to self for devs about work to do.

labels.name: Documentation
labels.description: Primary deliverable of this item is documentation

issue.body:
In the filter phase, we have a list of incoming messages.
* we expose them to all reject/accept clauses.
* there are messages which have not been explicitly matched.
What do we do with them?

Currently, we require a manual setting *acceptUnmatched* .

With *acceptUnmatched True*, those files are accepted.

*AcceptUnmatched on* is entirely equivalent to accept .*  (except it is faster because no regex to evaluate. (fixed by faf73a55b9304be800c6e287f339cf2b1ccd5fdb)

We set the default to a fixed value:

in flow/
     __init__.pt : False
    poll: False
    post: False
    report: True
   sarra: True
   sender: True
   subscribe: False
   watch: True
   winnow: True

ugh...  but I think the real issue here is whether there are accept/reject patterns provided.
If we want acceptUmatched to be set to something that makes sense, it would be based on the contents of the accept/reject patterns.

case 1: no patterns at all provided...

* if there are no accepts or rejects provided, then setting acceptUnmatched to False resorts in nothing ever being processed, which is useless. It makes more sense for it to be automatically set to True

case 2: only rejects in patterns... again results in nothing ever being accepted if the default is False... so again it makes sense to set it to True

case 3: only accepts in patterns... seems logical, anything not explicitly accepted is rejected.  So in this case, it should be set to False


case 4: mix of rejects and accepts... seems logical to reject anything not explicitly accepted. so it would be set to False.

If we take the above 4 cases

Say we apply logic: that uses the above four cases to decide what to do.


imagined case 5: started with only rejects...
```

reject my1.*
reject my4.*

```

so take case 2... only rejects in pattern.. so guessing that everything else is accepted... 
If you receive files   

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file

now say you add an accept...

```

reject my1.*
accept my2.*
reject my4.*

```

for the same input flow...

received flow: my1file, my2file, my3file, my4file, my5file.

accepted flow: my2file

according to case 4, now because you added an accept, acceptUnmatched flips to false so you surprisingly accept fewer files than before...

hmm...  Does that make this more confusing than helpful?

option 1: current state

it just is set to a default per flow, that makes sense.

in v2, many poll configurations from internal examples seem to expect *acceptUnmatched True*, but it is currently False.  Changine that...  ( 5b41ec299df655c1d113ce83820e26a529b3878d )

Ideally, the goal would be to get rid of acceptUnmatched, and just have it do the right thing always, but case 5, makes me thing that getting rid of it is inelegant.  Need a better idea for how to set it automatically.

issue.title: work.age not a good port of v2 file_age

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: Priority 2 - Critical
labels.description: High Criticality or High Visibility Problem

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
the file_age plugin notes how old a file is when a copy is done, by comparing
the time the plugin is called, to the file's mtime at source (recorded in the message.)

The file_age plugin was ported, literally, to work.age, and it does the same thing, 
but with the sr3 way of doing things, the same thing is the wrong thing.  in v2, on_file was called as each file was written, whereas in sr3, messages are processed in batches, so the on_file is called for an entire batch, after the batch has downloaded.   So the timing will be reported as much worse because the logic hasn't been adjusted.

Granted, you can set batch=1 to get v2 behaviour, but in general the transfers happen, and then, some time later, the after_work processing happens.

Fixing this requires some plumbing.  Probably want to add a message field ''timeWritten" ... to the send/download built-in logic ... and then use that in work.age.

note: Internal client (CMOI) uses this plugin as part of HPC mirroring. so this is a blocker for them moving to sr3

issue.title: flows taking a long time to exit

labels.name: likely-fixed
labels.description: likely fix is in the repository, success not confirmed yet.

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
So, in the name of ensuring state is saved, there is a signal handler in flow (please_stop) ... but the effect of that signal handler is to catch a sigterm signal, set please_stop flag, but that's it... if a flow is in a sleep... that sleep continues... so if you have a polling interval of 900 seconds, then it will wait to do the cleanup until after that sleep ends normally.

This is a pita in development, and likely will result in sr3 stop losing patience and doing a kill -9...
I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

comment.body: question remains about ebo sleep loops, should we add naps?

issue.title: Porting plugins from v2 to v3
issue.body:
When porting a plugin, it should be moved from the /plugin dir to the /flowcb dir. To group  them together, thinking of putting all on_message plugins (which become after_accept) into its own file directory called accept.

**So far the following plugins have been ported:**
*Note: some of these still have FIXMEs and TODOs to take care of since I wasn't always sure about the logic of the plugin*

Make your branch's PR reference this issue....

- Active Branch: v03_wip_plugins

- Waiting on sr3 implementation for the rest.. no touchy

    - The `on_data` entry point is not supported at the moment. it has the same problem as `on_html_data` (#426), being called from the `transfer/` classes rather than `flow/`
    - documented in eabfe7696be177f908b21b80d880ee2451f9bed6

    - The idea is to have sarra spew logs that look like PX so when people are porting PX->sarra they can log compare (vimdiff)

issue.title: flows taking a long time to exit

labels.name: v3
labels.description: issue deferred to or affects version 3

issue.body:
So, in the name of ensuring state is saved, there is a signal handler in flow (please_stop) ... but the effect of that signal handler is to catch a sigterm signal, set please_stop flag, but that's it... if a flow is in a sleep... that sleep continues... so if you have a polling interval of 900 seconds, then it will wait to do the cleanup until after that sleep ends normally.

This is a pita in development, and likely will result in sr3 stop losing patience and doing a kill -9...
I added a *please_stop_immediately* flag for now... but I think the real solution is for the please_stop signal handler to re-raise (?) the signal, to that sleep returns quickly and exit processing happens much faster.

issue.title: downloads fail with directory . specified

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on (outside development scope)

issue.body:
Specifying a dot character *.* as the argument to the directory option is not handled correctly by sarracenia version 2.

given a configuration like so:

```
broker amqps://dd.weather.gc.ca/

# expire, in operational use, should be longer than longest expected interruption
expire 10m
mirror on

subtopic bulletins.alphanumeric.#

directory .
accept .*

```

every download fails, like so:

```
022-12-01 15:32:18,554 [INFO] Binding queue q_anonymous.sr_subscribe.dd_amis.19381310.19639925 with key v02.post.bulletins.alphanumeric.# from exchange xpublic on broker amqps://anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca/
2022-12-01 15:32:18,556 [INFO] declared queue q_anonymous.sr_subscribe.dd_amis.19381310.19639925 (anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca)
2022-12-01 15:32:18,557 [INFO] reading from to anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca, exchange: xpublic
2022-12-01 15:32:18,559 [INFO] report_back to anonymous@dd.weather.gc.ca, exchange: xs_anonymous
2022-12-01 15:32:18,559 [INFO] sr_retry on_heartbeat
2022-12-01 15:32:18,564 [INFO] No retry in list
2022-12-01 15:32:18,566 [INFO] sr_retry on_heartbeat elapse 0.006780
2022-12-01 15:32:18,567 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,569 [WARNING] downloading again, attempt 2
2022-12-01 15:32:18,569 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,570 [WARNING] downloading again, attempt 3
2022-12-01 15:32:18,571 [ERROR] sr_subscribe/__do_download__: Could not download
2022-12-01 15:32:18,573 [INFO] appended to retry list file 20221201152828.419 https://dd2.weather.gc.ca /bulletins/alphanumeric/20221201/SR/KWAL/15/SRCN40_KWAL_011528___46900
```

work-arounds:

* since **directory .** specifies the default behaviour, remove that line. it will download correctly
* if you use sr3 instead of v2, the problem does not occur.
* you can specify **directory ${PWD}** and it will download correctly.

sample run with **directory** line removed:

2022-12-01 15:35:18,561 [INFO] file_log downloaded to: /tmp/bulletins/alphanumeric/20221201/SR/KWAL/15/SRCN40_KWAL_011528___14862
2022-12-01 15:35:18,572 [INFO] file_log downloaded to: /tmp/bulletins/alphanumeric/20221201/SP/CYSB/15/SPCN62_CYSB_011528___18122046
2022-12-01 15:35:18,582 [INFO] file_log downloaded to: /tmp/bulletins/alphanumeric/20221201/UA/CWAO/15/UANT01_CWAO_011529___32041

As it is fixed in version 3, and there are easy work-arounds, we don't expect to fix this problem.
